abstract: Harold Feinstein's Coney Island pictures recall the exuberance of a bygone era. Now, Jason Landry of the Panopticon Gallery in Boston hopes to memorialize his work in a retrospective book.
snippet: Harold Feinstein's Coney Island pictures recall the exuberance of a bygone era. Now, Jason Landry of the Panopticon Gallery in Boston hopes to memorialize his work in a retrospective book.
lead_paragraph: Harold Feinstein was just 15 when he first picked up a camera in his  Coney Island neighborhood in 1946. Over the next two decades, he produced an extraordinary body of work that in its day was lauded, collected and exhibited by the likes of the  Museum of Modern Art and Edward Steichen.

headline.main: With Feinstein Retrospective, a Bygone Era
